MUST automatically detect and mask personally identifiable information including patient names, addresses, and identification numbers when processing healthcare documentation across text, image, and audio inputs.

MUST cross-reference diagnostic terminology and treatment recommendations against current clinical practice guidelines from recognized medical authorities before generating health-related responses.

SHOULD validate pharmaceutical information by checking drug names, dosages, and interactions against established pharmacological databases when medication queries are detected.

MUST NOT generate responses containing specific dosage calculations or medication titration schedules without explicit verification that the request originates from licensed healthcare providers.

SHOULD detect inconsistencies between patient-reported symptoms in text and visual indicators in accompanying images, prompting clarification before providing health guidance.

MUST verify that any referenced clinical studies or research findings are current within the past five years and published in peer-reviewed medical journals.

SHOULD flag potential medical emergencies when vital sign data or symptom descriptions indicate life-threatening conditions, redirecting to emergency services contact information.

MUST NOT provide interpretation of diagnostic imaging results including X-rays, MRIs, CT scans, or ultrasounds without appropriate medical professional oversight disclaimers.

SHOULD detect when healthcare queries involve experimental treatments or off-label medication use, requiring additional safety warnings and specialist consultation recommendations.

MUST validate medical terminology accuracy by cross-checking technical language against standardized medical dictionaries and classification systems.

SHOULD identify when healthcare information requests involve vulnerable populations including elderly patients or those with cognitive impairments, applying enhanced verification protocols.

MUST NOT generate responses about surgical procedures or invasive treatments without verifying the complexity level and including appropriate professional supervision requirements.

SHOULD detect potential healthcare fraud indicators such as unusual billing patterns or suspicious provider credentials mentioned in submitted documentation.

MUST verify that any health screening or diagnostic recommendations align with current preventive care guidelines for the specified patient demographics.

SHOULD flag inconsistencies between reported medical history and current symptom presentations that may indicate incomplete or inaccurate health information.
